definitions.definition: The act of abandoning , or the state of being abandoned; total desertion ; relinquishment .
The voluntary leaving of a person to whom one is bound by a special relation , as a wife , husband or child ; desertion .
examples: Since he left her, she's suing him for divorce on grounds of abandonment .
High-profile abandonments are harder to infiltrate for urban explorers due to their heightened security.

definitions.definition: The relinquishment of a right, claim, or privilege; relinquishment of right to secure a patent by an inventor; relinquishment of copyright by an author.
The relinquishment by the insured to the underwriters of what may remain of the property insured after a loss or damage by a peril insured against.
The cessation of service on a particular segment of the lines of a common carrier , as granted by a government agency.
A refusal to receive freight so damaged in transit as to be worthless and render carrier liable for its value .
The self-surrender to an outside influence.
Abandon ; careless freedom or ease; surrender to one's emotions.

main_definition: The act of abandoning , or the state of being abandoned; total desertion ; relinquishment . [Late 16 century.]
secondary_definitions: The voluntary leaving of a person to whom one is bound by a special relation , as a wife , husband or child ; desertion .
( law ) The relinquishment of a right, claim, or privilege; relinquishment of right to secure a patent by an inventor; relinquishment of copyright by an author. [Early 19 century.]
( law ) The relinquishment by the insured to the underwriters of what may remain of the property insured after a loss or damage by a peril insured against. [Early 19 century.]
The cessation of service on a particular segment of the lines of a common carrier , as granted by a government agency.
A refusal to receive freight so damaged in transit as to be worthless and render carrier liable for its value .
The self-surrender to an outside influence. [Mid 19 century.]
Abandon ; careless freedom or ease; surrender to one's emotions. [Mid 19 century.]
